title: Mississippi dad has murder conviction reversed over 'shaking death' of baby daughter
text:
A Mississippi court has reversed the second-degree murder conviction of Joshua Clark who was accused of shaking his four-month-old to death in January 2008

A Mississippi court has reversed the second-degree murder conviction of a father accused of shaking his four-month-old daughter to death in 2008.

On Thursday, the state's Court of Appeals voted 7-3 to allow a new trial for Joshua Clark, after his defense attorney argued that 'shaken baby syndrome' has been proven to be 'junk science.'

Clark has been behind bars for almost 11 years, but may be eligible for bail in the coming months as he awaits the next trial, The Daily Journal reports.

Clark was left alone at his Itawamba County home with his infant daughter, Kylie Clark, for several hours on January 5 2008. During that time, he is alleged to have shaken the little girl, before his wife returned home to find the tot 'limp and lifeless on a recliner'.

Kylie was rushed to a nearby hospital before being transferred to a medical facility in Memphis, where doctors discovered that she had a fractured collar bone, fractured ribs and injuries to her eyes and brain.

Clark was promptly arrested and charged with capital murder. During his first trial, held in 2010, he accepted a deal and plead guilty to depraved heart murder. The father was sentenced to life in prison.

According to the Daily Journal, the decision was appealed on the grounds of ineffective counsel, with a second trial going to a jury in 2016.

The jurors found Clark not guilty of capital murder, but guilty of second degree murder. He was sentenced to 40 years in prison.

During that trial, medical expert Dr. Karen Lakin testified on behalf of the prosecution, claiming that the baby had been violently shaken by Clark.

Clark is pictured in prison. He has been behind bars for almost 12 years over the death of his daughter, Kylie

She claimed that shaking a young child in a violent fashion could be enough to cause a fatal brain injury.

However, Clark's defense attorney, Jim Waide, has pointed out that Dr. Lakin offered no medical studies or reports to back up the claim.

He further cited a 2016 study by the Swedish government which claimed there was 'insufficient scientific evidence on which to base a diagnosis of Shaken Baby Syndrome'.

“It has now been showed as junk science,' he told the Daily Journal.

The ruling on Tuesday agreed that Dr. Lakin didn't provide support for her claims in relation to Shaken Baby Syndrome.

Meanwhile, Clark remains behind bars for the time being.

'He is not free yet,' Waide told The Daily Journal. 'The state still has 14 days to ask the court for a rehearing. Or they could ask the [state] supreme court to hear it.'

authors: Mary Kekatos Health Reporter For Dailymail.Com
